entry.title: Combined summary - Fwd: Bitcoin Core trial balloon: splitting blockchain engine and wallet
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the benefits of having a separate process for running blockchain and wallet daemons in Bitcoin software. Mike Hearn notes that without a sandbox, a separate process would not offer any advantages. In an email discussion thread, Wladimir suggests running the blockchain daemon as a system service and the wallet daemon as the user which Dustin D. Trammell agrees with. James Hartig, a software engineer, mentions that using multiple wallets on the same blockchain process allows for running cheaper processes instead of having unused wallet functionality. He also adds that it gives the user flexibility to make it as secure as they feel comfortable. However, there is a desire to avoid implementing a complicated scheme that requires running things under multiple users.In another email exchange from 2014, William Yager suggests running the network part of the core as a system service may make sense for server implementations but not for most users. Wladimir responds by saying that making it a possibility wouldn't affect other use cases and questions if William is arguing just for the sake of arguing. In a discussion thread, Wladimir proposes running the blockchain daemon as a system service with its own uid/gid and set of Apparmor/SELinux restrictions while running the wallet daemon as the user. Dustin points out that this may not always be possible and suggests making it optional instead of forcing everyone to do it. However, he jokingly states that anyone not using his configuration should be punished by a special task force, and repeated offenders would lose their BitLicense.
